Info Source: Contained in data received from the agency on February 25, 2021 in response to an open records request. The data -- which in some cases merged penalty amounts from multiple violations --was a spreadsheet version of information contained in individual case documents that can be retrieved at https://www.ahs.dep.pa.gov/eFACTSWeb/default.aspx

Description: Prudential Equity Group LLC (PEG), a broker-dealer subsidiary of Prudential Financial Inc., entered into a deferred prosecution agreement in which PEG has admitted to criminal wrongdoing in connection with deceptive market timing trading in mutual fund shares dating back to 1999 and agreed to a payment of $600 million in fines, restitution and penalties.

Company: Prudential Equity Group, LLC f/k/a Prudential Securities Inc.
Description: The SEC announced settled enforcement actions against seven broker-dealers for failing to disclose they had received payments for providing research coverage of certain public companies, in violation of Section 17(b) of the Securities Act of 1933.
overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: Bouder et al v. Prudential Financial, Inc. et al

Description: off-the-clock work
Private Litigation Case Title: Prescott, et al. v. Prudential Insurance Company of America

Description: overtime violation
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re Wachovia Securities, LLC Wage and Hour Litigation

Description: The settlement total includes $8.4 million to the plaintiffs, $20.5 million in charitable contributions and $10.2 million for legal fees and expenses.  The case was brought by military families alleging that Prudential failed to pay death benefits under a group life insurance program.
Private Litigation Case Title: In Re: Prudential Insurance Company of America SGLI/VGLI Contract Litigation

Description: Prudential Equity Group, formerly known as Prudential Securities, agreed to pay $270 million to Massachusetts, New Jersey, New York and NASD to resolve allegations of improper market timing. This was part of a larger $600 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-prudential-equity-group-llc

The New York Attorney General announced that Prudential would pay $270 million in customer restitution to resolve allegations of unlawful trading of mutual funds through market timing. This was part of a larger $600 million civil and criminal settlement involving the U.S. Justice Department, which issued its own announcement; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-prudential-equity-group-llc

Private Litigation Case Title: Huffman et al v. The Prudential Insurance Company Of America

Description: Prudential agreed to pay $17 million to settle multistate litigation regarding its use of the Social Security Administration's Death Master File.
Info Source: Death Master' Investigation Results in National Settlement with Major Life Insurer, US State News, February 2, 2012 (via Nexis).

Description: Two subsidiaries of Prudential Financial Inc. -- AST Investment Services Inc. and PGIM Investments LLC -- agrred to pay a $5 million penalty and disgorge $27.6 million -- to settle allegations of failing to disclose conflicts of interest and making misleading disclosures to the boards for 94 funds they advised.

Metropolitan Life Insurance, Prudential Insurance Co. and Unum Insurance Co. agreed to pay a total of $1.1 million in settlement of allegations by three California District Attorneys that they paid illegal rebates to a brokerage firm to obtain business.

Company: The Prudential Insurance Company of America
Info Source: Extracted from a spreadsheet obtained from the NLRB through a Freedom of Information Act request fulfilled on 5/28/2020.

Company: The Prudential Insurance Company of America
Description: Prudential Insurance agreed to pay $700,000 costs in settlement of allegations it violated insurance regulations by failing to disclose details of compensation and contingent compensation for the Producer representing the policyholder.

Pruco agreed to pay a $750,000 fine and $150,000 in costs in settlement of allegations it failed to reasonably supervise its representatives and had an unsuitable system in place for calculating variable annuity transactions, resulting in inaccurate information for customers and a failure to provide information to the Department in a timely manner.

Company: The Prudential Insurance Company of America
The Prudential Insurance Company of America

Description: Prudential Insurance  Company of America, Pruco Insurance  Company of Iowa, Pruco Life Insurance  Company, Prudential Annuity Life Assurance Corporation, Prudential Retirement Insurance and Annuity  Company, and Pruco Life Insurance Company of New Jersey agreed to pay a $200,000 civil penalty in settlement of allegations their previous use of the automatic default option establishing a retained asset account could result in an unsuitable arrangement for a beneficiary, in violation of state regulations.

Company: The Prudential Insurance Company of America
Description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, Pruco Life Insurance  Company, Prudential Retirement Insurance  and Annuity Company, and Prudential Annuities Life Assurance Corporation (formerly known as American Skandia Life Assurance Corporation) agreed to pay $1 million to the state as part of a settlement of allegations they had inadequate procedures to ensure policies and other funds were timely investigated and paid out to beneficiaries.

Company: The Prudential Insurance Company of America
The Prudential Insurance Company of America

Description: Subsidiaries of Prudential Insurance Company of America were ordered to refund $25.1 million on 325,000 New Jersey automobile policies because they earned more profit than state law allowed.
Agency: New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance
Info Source: Prudential's N.J. Auto Subsidiaries Must Refund $25.1 Million to Policyholders, Bestwire, July 26, 2001 (via Nexis).

Description: Pruco Securities agreed to pay $100,000 in civil penalties in a settlement with the Bureau of Securities over violations of securities regulations that it self-reported when it discovered some of its agents were late in executing mutual fund transactions, leading to a change in prices.

Company: The Prudential Insurance Company of America
Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into consent orders with six life insurance companies to resolve alleged violations of New York Insurance Regulations in deferred to immediate annuity replacement transactions.  The insurers, collectively, agreed  to pay $1,152,154 in restitution and $673,000 in penalties.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Company: The Prudential Insurance Company of America

Agency: Wisconsin Office of the Commissioner of Insurance

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Prudential Annuities Distributors, Inc. $950,000 for failing to detect and prevent a scheme that resulted in the theft of approximately $1.3 million from an 89-year-old customer's variable annuity account.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authorit ordered Pruco Securities, LLC of Newark, New Jersey, to pay more than $10.7 million in restitution, plus interest, to customers who placed mutual fund orders with Pruco via facsimile or mail (paper orders) from late 2003 to June 2011 and received an inferior price for their shares. FINRA also fined Pruco $550,000 for its pricing errors and for failing to have an adequate supervisory system and written procedures in this area.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: FINRA settled cases against five firms for mutual fund sales and supervisory violations - including improper sales of Class B and Class C mutual fund shares and failure to have supervisory systems designed to provide all eligible investors with the opportunity to purchase Class A mutual fund shares at net asset value (NAV) through NAV transfer programs.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD censured and fined 29 securities firms over $9.2 million for more than 8,000 late disclosures of reportable information about their brokers, including customer complaints, regulatory actions, and criminal charges and convictions.
Info Source: NASD Fines 29 Firms over $9.2 Million for Late Reporting, PR Newswire, November 30, 2004 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD ordered eight firms to pay fines totaling $310,000 and restitution to customers of $300,000 in connection with certain municipal bond trades where customers did not receive a fair price for their bonds, in violation of Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board (MSRB) rules.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Company: Prudential Equity Group, Inc. and Prudential Investment Management Services LLC
Description: NASD fined Prudential Equity Group, Inc. (formerly known as Prudential Securities, Inc.) and Prudential Investment Management Services LLC, $2 million and ordered the firms to pay customers $9.5 million for sales of annuities, including variable annuities, that violated a New York State Insurance Department regulation and NASD rules.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Company: Prudential Retirement Insurance and Annuity Company
